Violation_Type: Failure to meet statutory residence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether the appellant met the residence requirement under subsection 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Appellant was absent from Canada for 636 days over a period of three years and three months; absences were frequent but brief, primarily for business
Court_Ruling: Appellant did not meet the required 1095 days of physical presence in Canada within the four years preceding the application
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada during the relevant period
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged compliance with residency requirements despite absences
Legal_Standard: Minimum 1095 days of physical residence in Canada within the four years before application
Assessment_Factor: Total number of days physically present in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court challenging Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of entries and exits, travel history
Application_Basis: Residency calculation based on physical presence
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and frequency of absences from Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturning of rejection and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have been physically present in Canada for at least 1095 days in the four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or presence to meet the 1095-day requirement
Harm_Assessment: No harm established due to non-compliance with legal requirement
Cause_Description: Appellant’s citizenship application was rejected due to insufficient residency days
Evidence_Handling: Travel records used to calculate days of physical presence
Residency_Compliance: Not compliant – 636 days absent, 537 days short of requirement
Decision_Rationale: The appellant failed to accumulate the minimum 1095 days of physical residence required by law
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, appeal reviewed by Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective calculation of physical presence under the Citizenship Act
